title: Network analysis of the competence centres in Slovenia

author: Alenka Pandiloska Jurak, Faculty of Information Studies

segmentation: I would like to present you joint paper written by Miss Gorton.
Mr Christine Dr Lujar, professor, professor Pintrich and myself.
Oh, we present results of research done on the network of civilian scholars.
We put special Focus 2 subnetworks, created by research Group forming the so called competence centers.
Each of these centers received approximately 6.5 million euro of research money to create new technological products and processes.
Our expectation was that this strong financial.
Financial impulses will also imply significant improvement of the network parameters with scribing size, productivity and connectivity of the centers.
We have realized that for these three centers that we took into considerations, this is not the case.
These are our main contributions of the research we apply state of the art network analysis methods to network spend by research groups included, and three out of seven approved competent center.

We rely on high quality data about research output of institutions included in the study, which is based on the two sensor publicly available and well maintained databases and our approach can be easily extended to.
Consider other type of research, research output, other network analysis methods, and other research policy measures.
As mentioned, we've used two basic data sources, that is secrets and copies which were integrated within the web application or represented by Mr. Mario Carlo jets.
We use it to create networks while all network parameters were calculated using Pike.
We compared results for the following three competent centers written on slide.
This centers were established to achieve.
One of the policy measures in research and development policy, which was defined in Slovenia's development strategy in 2005.

Well, despite of this competent centers instrument followed mainly the research policy required for all technological development and innovation, we claim that it should also stimulate the publication of new findings and discoveries mainly or specially partners coming from nonprofit members.
All will be graphical data of relevance.
Those are articles, chapters, monographies.
Patterns and so on was analyzed with focus on Co authorship where at least one coauthor comes from a profit and one from a nonprofit research group.
The financed collaboration should grow and develop as network much faster compared to the general network.
Regarding the following factors, the size, the productivity and the connectivity.
For each of the considered network, the following parameters were analyzed.
The network size, density, average degree, number of kinetic components, diameter and clustering coefficient.
See we're presenting the results for the factors for the network of all active groups registered in secrets.
We named it as all and for the sub networks.
We call them class, brain and story which are the acronyms.
The analysis was done on the cumulative networks for the time periods.
So these are the 1st results that we gained here.
Table one shows the development of total academic network called all.
As you can see here.
Oh, and three analyzed cases of the competent centers following below.
In all cases, we can see a significant growth of number of active research groups.
However, the group of competent centers networks is much more significant compared to the growth of the total network.

Further, on table two shows that coauthored publications get some kind of weak impulse in 2005, 2006 when research groups forming those competence centres later on start to publish together more intensively.
Every channel growth is more intensive for the 2nd two competent centers, while the complete network at class over here has approximately the same growth.
This growth is also seen on this graph, and it's probably more.
Visually and socially better OK.
Oh the next table shows the dynamics of cooperation between the profit and nonprofit research groups for network.

All one can observe almost linear growth rates, while for the three analyzed centers it is obvious that class subnetworks tired that on joint publications rather relate compared to other competent centers.
Density has two main characteristics.
First, it is low compared to the possible full density value and the second observation is that competent centers did not make any significant progress in joint publication.
This shows that the growth of competence centres networks were not followed by the new links between the groups with appropriate rate.
Since the number of new publications was also increasing.
This increase is mainly due to publications, effort of the existing Co authorship.
Then I'm mixing average degree shows how the average number of Co authoring groups for members of the centers is growing.
We see that the average degrees are increasing, but also the size of networks are increasing in the same cases even faster, resulting in the drop of the density.
It's interesting that the research groups in all that all together made much more progress in average degree than two out of three competence centers.
This is mainly because the size of the networks grew slower.
Table 6 so shows us the number of connected components or sub networks which are existing independently within the network.
Overtime it was expected that the number of sub networks should be reduced, which is also the case on the practical example.
However, it is also visible that according to the data, two out of three competent centers reached 100 coverage already of.
All of the networks already before introducing up competence center as their policy measure.
Oh Table 7 presents the greatest distance between any of two research groups which are part of the same network.

With increasing density of these networks, it is expected that any of two non Co authoring research groups will have to author with smaller number of research groups in order to be closer to another non related research group.
This is nicely visible in the case of total population where the drop from 5:50 is obvious as well as in case of brain wave drop from 6 to 3.
Is also significant.
Further on, the clustering coefficient presented on this table.
Credit crisis, the whole network and it could be seen as a measure of let's say, how close is considered network to a fully connected network of the same order.
Initial cooperation within the networks creating competent centers were significantly higher compared to network, all while at the end of the time interval the difference is much smaller.
It would be expected that the trend would be reversed.
Due to relatively small size of the networks and strong joint interest, but this is not the case as we have already observed when we were considering other parameters like density and average degree.
Oh well, this results presented show how well mainly how it is possible to use network analysis for understanding the dynamics of SoC, or some parts of SoC.
We believe that we show that the use of methods can be indirectly used for evaluating of certain public policy, which has measurable results as product of social interaction and networking.
We also need to revise our main research and we.
Uh, established or the establishment of computer centers did not significantly boost the coauthored publications in any of three centers compared to the whole population.
Networking potential of these centers measured by joint publications prior and after establishment of the centers did not change.
Furthermore, it is more valid to say that previous cooperation between research groups resulted in applying for the computer center financial instrument.
And last but not least, also joint publications written by private and public research groups did not disproportionally increase with establishment.
A stablishment and financing of our competent centers.
That would be a brief summary of our paper.
If there are any questions, please ask me or my colleagues with this paper.
Thank you.
